content.description:
CAUTION: I did minimal cleaning on this route for the protection and will come back to finish cleaning it. Its a full on gardening and vegetation climb especially near the top until I am done cleaning it.

 Fun moves and great climbing. It might be easier if you are taller.

 The route starts to the right of the boulder and goes up about 10 feet until its possible to "Step Over" left to the ledge to continue up. Continue up past a block. There is an alternate way up -- instead of stepping over and continuing straight up from the "Step Over" ledge, climb up to the small roof/block and then left.

 Anchor: A tree at the top.
content.protection:
A basic rack. Small cams up to #2. Tree anchor on top.

 I would not recommend for a new leader due to the protection in the beginning and the big boulder that is right under your feet with a possibility of a ledge fall if you don't stick the "Step Over" hence the PG13 rating.
content.location:
As you enter the playground area, it is the first route with a detached large boulder under the arete.

 The route starts just to the right of the boulder.

content.description: Climb up an easy, fun start.  Turn right to face the rook.  As it gets overhung, use the crack on the left, until you can traverse out, and pull up to the ledge.  Climb the much easier section to the top.
content.protection: Setting an anchor at the top of this climb will prove tricky.  I saw only two, quite small boulders.
content.location: The right-most climb in the Playground.  Look up to the right of the roof, you can't miss the giant, protruding crown of the rook.

content.description: Up the short wall to a large ledge then head up towards the small roof to another ledge
content.location: Best to setup the anchor on natural anchors above between Illinois Flake and Departure.

content.description: A height-dependent climb; your reach can make this feel easier or harder. Climb between Economy Class Airfare and Darmakaya and through the center of the roof to the top. Can share anchor with Economy Class Airfare.
Climb up the thin cracks past the Illinois shaped flake up to the roof and up near the boulder above.
content.protection: TR Boulders and Trees above, some thin questionable places for pro
content.location: 8 ft to the right of Fine Pine Line

content.description:
The name of this route refers to the history of Sky Top's historic Hardware Route, which marked the first appearance of hammers at the Gunks.

 The route is recognizable by the bolt that acts as the first piece of gear. It features face climbing on edges. This route shares its topout with Fine Pine Line (if the roof for that route is exited on the left).
content.protection: One bolt and one pin; and a standard rack. I didn't place anything bigger than a .75 on the face. Small cams were helpful. You'll need more cams for the anchor.
content.location: Just left of Fine Pine Line; also recognizable by a pin 3/4 of the way up.

content.description: Climb the crack up to a roof. I exited left, but it seems as if you can also exit right.
content.protection: nuts and cams make it G. You can build an anchor at the top, or go waaay back to find a tree that isn't a pitch pine.
content.location: Clean crack capped by a large roof in the Playground area.

content.description: Climb the corner and up left of the arete to the top
content.location: To the right of Departure, shares a natural anchor with Knuckle Dragger

content.description: Look at the steepest face in the Playground; there, just left of the obvious pillar that is The Rook.  See that vague weakness right out the middle of the overhangs?  That's Dharmakaya.  Beautiful white rock down low, powerful moves through the upper section.
content.protection: Easy to TR (bolts at the top), but has been led without undue fuss (assumes you're up to the challenge - you're very unlikely to stop to get gear once the hard work begins.  And the fall would be large.)
content.location: Between the left-facing corner of Departure (look for the bolts at the top of this) and the Rook pillar.

content.description: Climb to a ledge, wipe your feet off, and continue up to the top of the cliff.
content.protection: Double bolted with rap rings at the top.

content.description:
Fairly vertical for a 5.5, this climb has good feet and decent hands that justify the grade.

 Not a great route for a budding leader--the pro is mostly in flaring cracks and some of it is hard to place, so if you're not good with your placements it could be dangerous. On the other hand, a 5.5 climber leader who wants to challenge their head game could find this instructional.
content.protection: Small to middle-sized cams. Tricams would be better than cams in a lot of the placements.
content.location: This starts at a large right-facing jug. Continue basically straight up, along the path of least resistance.

content.description: This area extends from the pair of huge white pine trees, rightwards to the huge, imposing roof. The roof has a couple projects but apparently no completed routes yet.
